title: Venezuela: Citibank Trains Students in Virtual Banking Program
summary: Caracas, Venezuela - For more than a decade, Citibank Venezuela and its partner NGO, Jóvenes Emprendedores, have offered Bancos en Acción, the first and only contest in the country that teaches high school students about banking with an exclusive simulator component.
tag-1: Venezuela: Citibank Trains Students in Virtual Banking Program
tag-3: Caracas, Venezuela – For more than a decade, Citibank Venezuela and its partner NGO, Jóvenes Emprendedores, have offered Bancos en Acción, the first and only contest in the country that teaches high school students about banking with an exclusive simulator component.
tag-4: The winner this year, the 12th year the contest has been offered, was a team of junior-year students from María Auxiliadora Technical School. Filis Ramírez, Franco Charama and Anderson Barreto worked with Citi volunteer Kisbeth Murga.
tag-5: Second place went to Sindy Díaz, Génesis Osuna and Julia Julca, led by Citi volunteer Lismel Quero. Geisy Mendoza, Henry Abreu and Rafael Faría, along with their volunteer, Karl Marklund, came in third.
tag-6: Bancos en Acción has benefited more than 3500 high school juniors and seniors in Caracas public schools, teaching them about finance, financial products and services, and the role banks play in competitive markets.
tag-7: "Bancos en Acción creates a dynamic that allows students to act like bankers, developing their analytical, research and decision-making skills," explained Nelson Acosta, President of Citibank Venezuela. "The young people who participate become aware of the impact such decisions have on household and national economies. The program also influences families, as students teach their relatives about investment, debts, and managing their bank accounts and finances."
tag-8: Citibank awarded the first- through third-place teams (nine students) with educational support to help them attain further achievements and a better quality of life via the Human Resource Training, Technical and Employment Program offered by SUPERATEC, a Citibank partner NGO. The program provides training in information technology that empowers individuals to become better prepared to find a job or pursue a higher education. Members of the winning team also received a Siragon 1420 personal computer.
tag-9: The competition This year's contest was held over four weeks using specially designed software. The 75 high-school students, grouped into teams of three, became the managers a virtual bank. Under the guidance of 25 Citi volunteers, they made decisions about interest rates, loans, investments and savings. Each decision had repercussions for the market as well as the individual teams and was reflected in the Bank Performance Index (BPI), which measured success on the basis of such criteria as net earnings, earnings per share, net capital, loan and deposit share and capital quota. The winner was the bank with the highest BPI.
tag-10: A lasting impact The program is a great experience for the Citi volunteers, who, year after year, take away more from it than they put in. According to Mileivy La Cruz, a volunteer from the bank's Collection Unit, "Bancos en Acción has a lasting impact on the students who participate. They themselves describe the way their thinking evolved, how they started the program thinking that banking is just about deposits, withdrawals and a few branches. When they finish the program they understand much more about how a bank operates, and they learn that decision-making is the most important element of a profitable business and everything they will go on to do in life. Their success will depend on it.
tag-11: "My group this year was very special," La Cruz continued. "They really wanted to win, and they were very eager to learn and participate. They taught me something new every day, and I am very glad to have been able to make a mark on their professional as well as personal growth. That's why to me, Bancos en Acción is priceless."
tag-12: Beginnings Bancos en Acción was launched in Argentina in 1996 through an agreement between Citibank and Junior Achievement. It was soon extended to Europe and Canada, crossing borders, languages and nationalities. It was introduced to the rest of Latin America in 1998.
